title: When will Tesla release a software update that adds off-ramp capabilities to its Autopilot system?
preds: anybody hear from the oracles yet?
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Question becomes: what decision will the judges make.  Off ramp capability, as defined in the question and the related links, has already been implemented.  Either the question will close retroactively, or it seems there will be no positive outcome by year end.

Submitted Q for resolution based on the following article:
From: http://time.com/money/4504594/tesla-autopilot-8/
---"The changes to the system include: ....."
---"Auto-steer that navigates highway interchanges;" From the "more info" section of this Q: "A Tesla 8.0 software ...., and is rumored to include a new Autopilot feature that allows the car to exit the highway onto an off-ramp after the driver activates the turn signal (electrek). It is clear that the ability to "exit" a highway and "enter" another, using exit and entrance ramps, meets the questions specific definition of"off ramp" capability.  Tesla may have made a smart move, by limiting the technology to "highway interchanges", they appear to avoid the problems associated with exiting a highway onto regular streets, etc.

Surely it is over now... and don't call me surely...
"Autopilot can now automatically navigate highway on- and off-ramps."
https://www.cnet.com/roadshow/news/tesla-8-0-update-autopilot-cabin-overheat-protection-update/

http://www.bbc.com/news/technology-37426442
Tonight's update will presumably have some marginal effect on the ability of hackers to off-ramp you onto the road to HongKong....

Off-ramp service needs more detailed on-board information about the layout of specific ramp sites. This is more complicated than following lane markings, which can be achieved without much local knowledge.

I didn't know much about this outfit before these Qs started to pop up.  This guy overpromises so much you'd think he's running for office.  The more I know about Musk and Tesla, the less I like them.  That, however, does not seem to be the point of this or any other question.  Too bad.
Elon Musk says that update 8.0 will be released starting tomorrow (sept 21), which should include off-ramp capability for autopilot. http://fortune.com/2016/09/16/tesla-autopilot-8/
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

In the fine tradition of "MISSION ACCOMPLISHED," one supposes this will be settled on the basis of Tesla's claims rather than actual reality.  No other way to do it, I suppose, there being no practical way to wait for the body count.

Musk "hopes" release is next Wednesday, provided there are no last minute issues.
http://www.theverge.com/2016/9/16/12939294/tesla-autopilot-update-8-availability Since the Telsa fatality rate now seems be be no better than the rate for an average driver, in an average car; should release something soon.
I am probably going to be sorry I believed Musk about this.  Oh well....
adjust with more info on Tesla news

CEO Elon Musk revealed details about Tesla 8.0, its biggest software update yet. The update, which is slated to roll out worldwide in a week or two, will include significant updates to Tesla’s semi-autonomous driving system called Autopilot. Musk said Tesla has improved the accuracy of Autopilot by making more use of the radar sensor on Tesla vehicles. Until now, the radar sensor has been a supplementary sensor, but now it will play a greater role in determining whether the car should brake or not. The camera and imaging processing system that currently powers the semi-autonomous system will still be used. As part of the software update, Tesla’s Autopilot will also be able to automatically take off-ramp exits and will have improved Autosteering.As part of the software update, Tesla’s Autopilot will also be able to automatically take off-ramp exits
http://www.businessinsider.com.au/elon-musk-announces-tesla-80-autopilot-update-2016-9?r=US&IR=T
Elon Musk says so in his blog! If it doesn't happen in the next couple of weeks there's plenty of time to adjust forecasts.

As part of the software update, Tesla's Autopilot will also be able to automatically take off-ramp exits and will have improved Autosteering. 
http://uk.businessinsider.com/elon-musk-announces-tesla-80-autopilot-update-2016-9?r=US&IR=T
Tesla has announced that autopilot 8.0 will go live in 1-2 weeks. It looks to me like that includes something that will qualify as "off-ramp capability" as defined in this question.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Tesla announced today that Autopilot 8.0 should be released in two weeks.  It is supposed to have off ramp capabilities

Based on today's blog post, it seems most likely that the v8.0 will be including off-ramp capabilities as the update mentions it in the release notes: "Will take highway exit if indicator on (8.0) or if nav system active (8.1). Available in the United States initially"

The definition used in the Q, "Tesla 8.0 software update ... is rumored to include a new Autopilot feature that allows the car to exit the highway onto an off-ramp after the driver activates the turn signal"
This definition seems to set the definition of "off ramp capability" for the resolution of this Q.  This capability seems very similar to current lane change technology.

Based on the description of "off ramp capabilities" used by the press:
From: http://autoweek.com/article/technology/tesla-will-update-autopilot-safety-features-following-accidents
Michigan is moving forward with laws regarding autonomous vehicles quickly...

Last week, CEO Elon Musk said that the update was going to final review and added that “the amount of work [for Autopilot] that has been going into version 8.0 will be very noticeable”. We’ve already discussed the new automatic off-ramp feature, but now Electrek has learned that the new version, building on the off-ramp feature, will be able to handle highway interchanges without disengaging the Autopilot… That means that with v8.0, Autopilot will be able to automatically (always under the driver’s supervision) drive from one highway to another with the simple activation of the turn signal.
https://electrek.co/2016/08/29/tesla-autopilot-v8-0-highway-interchanges/
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Tesla has previously claimed that the 8.0 autopilot update will contain off-ramp capability, but has delayed release since July- with an end date not in sight. However, Elon Musk claims that only minor revisions remain, making it likely that the update will push prior to October 31st, but not guaranteed to have off-ramp capability.

One supposes that the source for these "capabilities" will be Tesla, although to the rest of us "capability" implies that it will actually work.  Still, they may have the common decency to wait until they've tested it first.  Stay tuned.

Musk is saying "in a few weeks". Not sure if he means 3-4 weeks or, like, ten. Not sure if he's sure. https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/771005524322033665 https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/771006527498969088 But he's postponed the blog post with the details. https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/771446048262946816 Probably dealing SpaceX issues.
Raising near term forecast: "Off ramp capabilities" could mean almost nothing.
Recent tweet today may have major update coming before the 31 Oct and may very well include the off-ramp update as well.

Elon Musk said today that major improvements to Autopilot are coming soon.  I am therefore taking up my forecast to 25% (prior 20%) by 10/31/2016 and simultaneously lowering by forecast to 70% (prior 75%) for 11/1/2016 - 12/31/2016 period
Moderating slightly on another reported crash.

From: http://www.iol.co.za/business/international/tesla-crash-lawsuit-in-the-offing-2060934
"I used Autopilot all the time on that stretch of the highway,” Molthan, 44, said in a phone interview. “But now I feel like this is extremely dangerous. It gives you a false sense of security. I’m not ready to be a test pilot. It missed the curve and drove straight into the guardrail. The car didn’t stop - it actually continued to accelerate after the first impact into the guardrail.”
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
The tesla laywers will push to slow things down until the heat cools off.  Easiest way is to continue testing the beta longer.
Death a few months back during car automation set program back.  And how will self driving cars be governed?  Too many questions to answer before January 17'.

I'd expect it to be part of the v8 update, as what Elon Musk referred to as "material improvements to the autonomy" of the care, and in response to Tesla's high-profile first fatal autopilot crash. With the beta testing phase lasting from the end of June to the end of August, which we are told is longer than usual and has delayed release of the update, it makes sense to think that the final review will be expedited and not take longer than the beta phase. https://electrek.co/2016/08/23/tesla-v8-0-operating-system-final-review-elon-musk/

Based on their development cycle, I would expect it this year. There have been delays, but Musk is now saying that 8.0 is "hopefully" going to a final review. This might indicate the developers are having more difficulty than expected, but I would still expect it to release this year. https://electrek.co/2016/08/23/tesla-v8-0-operating-system-final-review-elon-musk/
Tesla's announcement today is related to new battery packs for Model S and Model X, not related to Autopilot software.  I am taking my probabilities back to my original estimates

Elon Musk tweet that Tesla will make a product announcement at 12PM PT today.  I believe it could be related to the Software Update and therefore increase my probabilities of it happening sooner vs. later
Unlikely for it to come out so fast, and also usually things are announced in last quarter of year, but not released till next year, unless it's something that makes good holiday gift.

First announced in industry press July 4.  Still in beta.  Uncertain as to whether the upgrade will be a full release.  Still has the government enquiry to manage. As well as SEC on information to investors.   https://electrek.co/2016/07/04/tesla-autopilot-update-version-8-0-fatal-crash/
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Until they sort out why their cars keep ramming into things, this would seem a marketing mistake.  On the other hand, the Tesloids have shown no obvious interest in making sure anything actually works before selling it to the True Believers.  You and I might test this relentlessly for many months, but you and I are not Tesla, headed by the One True Prophet who has discovered that some percentage of the wealthy will buy the trendiest of anything and the lawyers will make things right at the funeral.  (Could it be that "Tesla" is a misprint for "Testless"?) One hopes that even their chutzpah will not be sufficient for them to spring this in the next couple of months, but year-end is not out of the question.  The model of probity to look at is Bill Gates or Donald Trump, for whom the rush to make money has always outweighed (okay, trumped) any impulse to ensure quality or safety or even hygiene.
Generally bearish TSLA progress, + good authority has 100% against in 2016.
This is included in version 8 which is currently in Beta testing.
It probably won't work, but it will be released before 2016!

Article describes "off-ramp" capability as using the "turn signal" to move to the exit lane:    ".... as the 8.0 version will further improve the technology’s performance on highways with the new “automatic off-ramp with the turn signal.”   Calling the feature "off-ramp" may over sell the feature the same way "autopilot" did.  Still keeping a low forecast.  Even if "off-ramp" is only a variant of "lane-change", the fear of how drivers will use it may delay the release. http://www.thecountrycaller.com/46814-tesla-motors-inc-tsla-releases-new-autopilot-features-refreshes-ui-via-80-update/

From today's FT, p11:
"Raj Nair, Ford's chief technical officer, said Ford had decided to leap to full autonomy "because we have not found a technology that can ensure driver engagement (when not in control)."
They want to make sure they get it right.

Tesla is facing increased regulatory scrutiny after a reported Autopilot fatality. They are also dealing with regulatory oversight of their acquisition of Solar City, as well as ongoing financial juggling to ensure delivery of the Model 3. They will likely slow the pace of updates for autonomy to avoid undue regulatory drag on the company - unless they feel that the feature will drive sales of Model 3.
There's a lot of talk about the UI update in 8.0 on the internet but much less so about the off-ramp capabilities. At this stage it seems like wishful thinking to me to expect it anytime soon.

I'm sure it is already in the works, but it will not only need to judge the curve of the ramp, but lanes, traffic and the carpool lights where applicable. I don't see it happening in the next four months. Maybe about 6-12 months before software is actually added, after testing of course.

Tesla is in danger of a major 'fear backlash' and more than one person Tesla will have heard the recent Revisionist History podcast talking about the Toyota unintentional acceleration events. Deaths caused by driver error that can easily be blamed on mechanical problems would cause major distress, and after a recent reported death of one driver, I can't imagine Tesla rolling out an expansion of this feature set.
one of many things: Tesla AI will need to deal w/human drivers who won't yield to Tesla cars.
This requires capabilities of software well above A-pseudo-I. The visual recognition needed for driverless cars is not there and will not be there for at least 5 years.

Based on Telsa's history of software releases (v4 12/7/2012, v5 8/14/2013, v6 9/19/2014, v7 10/10/2015) it seems like we get a major software release once a year.  The longest time between releases was 401 days between v5 and v6, which implies that v8 should come on 11/14/2016 Musk tweeted in July 2016 that v8 is taking longer than expected, seems like still 2016 release since he talks about meeting with the "design team" sounds more cosmetic vs. functional With regards to functionality, Tesla rolled out its Summon feature in v7.1 update.  The off-ramp capabilities seem less complicated vs. Summon and similar to the lane change feature already part of Autopilot I still put a decent chance for a 2017 release given Tesla is dealing with Model S production ramp, Gigafactory, and SolarCity acquisition, so its possible that timing could slip if Musk's attention is elsehwere http://www.teslarati.com/everything-need-to-know-tesla-software-updates/ https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/754804233107562496?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw
I believe it is very hard to ensure safety and reliabilty of such a function. This requires a lot of testing time, and as such may be abailable in maybe 6 months earliest.
Software testing prior to release requires lots of time.  Given recent history it could be assumed that Tesla would do a thorough set of tests in the interest of safety.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

They have already had issues in the public with the existing service which provides highway Autopilot, such as the recent fatality. Enhancing it to be usable off-ramp so soon is a potential PR problem, before they're fully confident with the highway variant.

Short time frame and legal problems all mixed with the stress on the financial side created by the buyout os Solar City that will impose to Elon Musk a minimum of new dangerous risks that do not benefit to the bottomline
No basis, but software updates are usually delayed. Off ramp capabilities is harder than Tesla's engineers think it is, and I doubt their ability to successfully complete Hello World on the first go.
Something that works in beta is only about 30℅ compete. If they spent 6 months working in it, that would mean it will take an additional 18 months.

Will NTSB Apply Brakes to Tesla's Autopilot? http://www.eetimes.com/document.asp?doc_id=1330098
I am increasingly finding parallels between Tesla Motors the company and Malcolm Gladwell the pundit. Hip, cool, innovative, but full of flaws and a little showy. In his recent podcast, Gladwell discusses the Toyota unintended acceleration case, failing to mention NASA's involvement and code glitches... For our purposes, this article hints that future regulatory oversight will prevent Tesla's OTA's without a previous software analysis. Whether Tesla will move with this OTA before a minimum of such oversight is in place is dubious, considering the consequences, complexity and timing issues.

Off ramp capability would likely need to navigate rapid increases and decreases in elevation, rapid changes in speed possibly ending with a stoplight or sign, sharper turns than normal highway driving, and sometimes Unexpected mergers and road splits.  I am not certain how far the "off ramp" capability would extend from the expressway, but, road conditions may also change rapidly, from being leaf covered in the fall, to snow and ice covered in the winter, possibly moving from a well maintained interstate highway onto an unmarked winding pothole filled gravel road. Given the NTSB investigation into the current list of Tesla Autopilot accidents, it seems unlikely that there would be a mass distribution of the new capability, before the current issues are resolved.  Launching this type of software going into the winter months of the US might not be the safest testing opportunity.  On the other hand, Tesla wants to push the envelope, and reports are that the Beta version is already being road tested.  Another uncertainty for question resolution may be the country location of the download.  Tesla could make the "Off Ramp" software available in limited worldwide areas, excluding the US. How widely the software needs to be distributed to meet the question criteria seems uncertain. National Traffic Safety Board has an ongoing investigation into Tesla technology.
http://www.eetimes.com/document.asp?doc_id=1330098
http://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Pages/HWY16FH018-preliminary.aspx

Hard to say.  Whenever they release it, it probably won't work, but that's not the question.  If anybody there had any capacity for humility, they'd test it and test it and test it and test it before releasing it, and then they'd test it some more.  One lacks confidence that they will do this.
